name: Barbary Macaque
description: It is a sturdy monkey with an elongated snout. It has silvery to brownish fur, a dark pink face, and no tail. Males are larger than females, though they otherwise look similar. Like all macaques, they have strong jaws, long canines, and cheek pouches extending to the neck.
spread_note: Lives in the mountains of North Africa; also introduced to the Rock of Gibraltar
image_alt: Barbary Macaque, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 47–75 cm; tail length 0–20 cm; weight 4–15 kg
attractions: They are the only primates (besides humans) living in Europe. The social life of Barbary macaques follows relatively strict rules. Troops can have up to 40 members, centered around females with young. Unlike most other macaques, male Barbary macaques participate in caring for the offspring.
breeding: The history of keeping Barbary macaques dates back to the zoo’s beginnings. In 1934, the death of a female was recorded, though details of her arrival or age are missing. They reappeared in 1960, when three arrived from Paris Zoo. From 1969, there was a 20-year gap until 1989, when we imported two pairs—one from Chomutov Zoopark, the other from Morocco via Ravensden. These left in 1998 due to the planned demolition of the monkey pavilion, and new animals settled into the updated exhibit with ungulates in 2000.
